<p>In 2015, the Department Psychology of the LMU Munich started to <a href="http://www.nicebread.de/open-science-hiring-practices/">require an open science statement</a> from applicants for a professorship position. Since then, four more professorship were announced using the same requirement:</p>
<blockquote>"Our department embraces the values of open science and strives for replicable and reproducible research. For this goal we support transparent research with open data, open material, and pre-registrations. Candidates are asked to describe in what way they already pursued and plan to pursue these goals."</blockquote>
<p>Today, another position has been announced using the same statement: <a href="http://jobs.zeit.de/jobs/muenchen_professur_w2_fuer_klinische_psychologie_und_psychotherapie_152537.html?wt_zmc=nl.int.zonpmr.jobnewsletter.2018-01-18.stellenmarkt.textlink.selektion.x&amp;c=429152&amp;si=qBad04Sbm08t1mUV5uQYKWEdSm6es4egoFdnXVrU2mTUNSSUSKLgArjblpxl2ksMcXOIIG9zq0W8AQNhqqMvw&amp;utm_medium=nl&amp;utm_campaign=jobnewsletter&amp;utm_source=2018-01-18&amp;wt_cc1=static.6">Professur (W2) auf Zeit (6 Jahre/tenure track) für Klinische Psychologie und Psychotherapie</a>. Jean-Claude Burgelman (Directorate General for Research and Innovation of the European Commission) says that “<a href="http://www.euroscientist.com/jean-claude-burgelman-the-new-open-science-paradigm-requires-fine-tuning/">the career system has to gratify open science</a>”. More and more universities add an explicit commitment to open science in their hiring practices. See <a href="https://osf.io/7jbnt/">this OSF project</a> for an incomplete collection of such job advertisements.</p>
